items.body:
Hi, 
Thank you for this great package. 

 I have tried the KNNWithMeans function of Surprise for a little while.
And I found that when k=1, the predicting person is chosen as his nearest neighbor. Let say I wanted to find nearest neighbor for “subj_A", the result I got was “subj_A" himself.

I think the prediction should exclude the person who is being predicted from similarity matrix 
(For example, make his correlation to be 0). 

What do you think ?

items.title: FileExistsError due to race condition when creating builtin dataset directory
items.body:
#### Description
The creation of the dataset directory is not thread-safe and is subject to race condition.

This can sometimes result in the following uncaught exception: `FileExistsError: [Errno 17] File exists: '/root/.surprise_data/'`.

The affected method is displayed below. The condition checking if the folder exists and if not creating the directory is subject to race conditions as `os.makedirs(folder)` will fail if the directory exists.

File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/surprise/builtin_datasets.py", line 23, in get_dataset_dir
```python
def get_dataset_dir():
    '''Return folder where downloaded datasets and other data are stored.
    Default folder is ~/.surprise_data/, but it can also be set by the
    environment variable ``SURPRISE_DATA_FOLDER``.
    '''

    folder = os.environ.get('SURPRISE_DATA_FOLDER', os.path.expanduser('~') +
                            '/.surprise_data/')
    if not os.path.exists(folder):
        os.makedirs(folder)

    return folder
```

This problem and two possible solutions for it are described in https://stackoverflow.com/a/42545343 .

This error has been observed when using the library in an application served by `gunicorn` with multiple `gthread`s.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

TODO: provide minimal code example.


#### Expected Results

If the builtin dataset directory already exists, it will be ignored or `FileExistsError` will be caught and ignored.

#### Actual Results

In a setup with multiple threads the library might throw a `FileExistsError` due to a race condition.

#### Versions
```
In [1]: import platform; print(platform.platform())                                                                                                                                                                                       
Darwin-19.4.0-x86_64-i386-64bit

In [2]: import sys; print("Python", sys.version)                                                                                                                                                                                          
Python 3.7.7 (default, Mar 10 2020, 15:43:33) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]

In [3]: import surprise; print("surprise", surprise.__version__)                                                                                                                                                                          
surprise 1.1.0
```

I see the below definition for build_anti_test function in your documentation.

"Return a list of ratings that can be used as a testset in the test() method.The ratings are all the ratings that are not in the trainset, i.e. all the ratings rui where the user u is known, the item i is known, but the rating rui is not in the trainset. items.title: Time- and/or User-based Cross-Validation
items.body:
#### Description
First off,  I want to thank you for your work on surprise.  This is a very cool library with a lot of potential.  Thank you for your time and effort!

I was looking over the provided tools for cross-validation.  They do not seem to be aware of the time of the ratings or how ratings are associated with users.  In my real-world contexts, you are going to deploy a recommendation system that uses past data to predict future events.  E.g., generate predictions for users based on all data available to the system prior to today.  Further, you may want to train and evaluate on different subsets of users.  I think that expanding the available options for cross-validation would help users perform more realistic experiments.

That said, I understand that Rome wasn't built in a day!  I think you've done an awesome job of establishing a strong foundation for the code base, documentation, etc.  I look forward to seeing how this library evolves and even using it in my classes as it matures.

(I worked on recommendation systems for online advertising in industry and am now a  professor at a small college.)

Hi, 

I plan to design a recommendation system, especially with Scikit-Surprise. 
A bit of background: I want to recommend products to shop. Here, the user is the shop and the items are products (water, chocolate, cheese,...).
So to create the scores and the rating matrix, I use a quota calculation that I normalize to get a score between 0 and 1, where 1 means that the store is the biggest

Second question, I want my system to take into account the time of year. For example it recommends more chocolate at Christmas.
How can I do that ? I have an idea where I do "post-filtering", (at the end, when I already compute SVD or system like this). So in thgis idea, I try to modify the rating of 
a product according to the period of the year and according to the evolution of the sales of this product on the sales history. So if the product is very well sold,

Do you think this is a good idea? Do you have any suggestions for doing this? Does Scikit-Surprise have any features to help me do this?

However, from your blog post, I understand that SVD with SGD works with matrices that contain missing ? values. For example, user 2 hasn't rated item 2.

Therefore, when I load data - how do I represent record `2, 2, ?`. Is this record removed from the dataset? Or is it stored as `2, 2, np.nan`?

James

items.title: Train test split per user ratings
items.body:
Dear Nicolas Hug,

first of all i want to tell you that your library is interesting.

However, I just checked your library and see that the train test split is not on the level of the user or what? Do you support a train test split that goes to every user's profile and hides a percentage of his ratings? For example, if we need a 4-fold cross validation evaluation protocol, we have to go to every user and hide the 25% of his ratings and try to predict the hidden ones with the rest 75% which will be used for training data..The evaluation protocol should run four times so that every time random item ratings should be placed to the two train-test sets (75 and 25) per user ..

A second comment is this. I tried to verify the results of MMLite and Librec with your library for the item recommendation task and I failed. I get for top-5 recommended items, a precision of 92% for ML-100k and 5-fold cross validation for your library with SVD method. This is impossible!!!!! 
Please notice that wRMF or BPR algorithm attain around 40% precision in the aforementioned libraries for the item recommendation task (or else item ranking) as can be seen in the following link

https://www.librec.net/release/v1.3/example.html

I have verified the same results already with another python-based implementation that I have in my ownership!!! What is different in your case? Why we get this huge precision values?

For the computation of precision, I used the following code from your library:

```py
from collections import defaultdict
from surprise import Dataset
from surprise import SVD
from surprise.model_selection import KFold


def precision_recall_at_k(predictions, k=10, threshold=3.5):
    '''Return precision and recall at k metrics for each user.'''

    # First map the predictions to each user.
    user_est_true = defaultdict(list)
    for uid, _, true_r, est, _ in predictions:
        user_est_true[uid].append((est, true_r))

    precisions = dict()
    recalls = dict()
    for uid, user_ratings in user_est_true.items():

        # Sort user ratings by estimated value
        user_ratings.sort(key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True)

        # Number of relevant items
        n_rel = sum((true_r >= threshold) for (_, true_r) in user_ratings)

        # Number of recommended items in top k
        n_rec_k = sum((est >= threshold) for (est, _) in user_ratings[:k])

        # Number of relevant and recommended items in top k
        n_rel_and_rec_k = sum(((true_r >= threshold) and (est >= threshold))
                              for (est, true_r) in user_ratings[:k])

        # Precision@K: Proportion of recommended items that are relevant
        precisions[uid] = n_rel_and_rec_k / n_rec_k if n_rec_k != 0 else 1

        # Recall@K: Proportion of relevant items that are recommended
        recalls[uid] = n_rel_and_rec_k / n_rel if n_rel != 0 else 1

    return precisions, recalls


data = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')
kf = KFold(n_splits=5)
algo = SVD()

for trainset, testset in kf.split(data):
    algo.fit(trainset)
    predictions = algo.test(testset)
    precisions, recalls = precision_recall_at_k(predictions, k=5, threshold=4)

    # Precision and recall can then be averaged over all users
    print(sum(prec for prec in precisions.values()) / len(precisions))
    print(sum(rec for rec in recalls.values()) / len(recalls))
```

best,


Dr. Panagiotis Symeonidis

items.body:
Hi Nicholas,
I was looking at the computation of precision and recall 

        # Precision@K: Proportion of recommended items that are relevant

items.body:
I have data with purchases at the store level (no product info).

for example:

```
John Smith    MCDonalds    $4
John Smith    Burger King    $0
Mary Jones   Burger King     $10
Mary Jones   Sports Shop    $50

etc

I noticed that all the tutorials are for data with products (i.e. "explicit rating data" according to the docs)

Is it possible to use this library to recommend stores based on purchase history? Has anybody tried this before? Could purchases be used as a rating perhaps? And if it's not recommended to use this library for my dataset, any suggestions on where to look? I guess my data is more "implicit"?

Thanks

items.title: This package sucks!!!
Computing MAP@K
items.body:
I wanted to know if this example: [https://surprise.readthedocs.io/en/stable/FAQ.html] computes the MAP@K instead of precision and recall only. To be more precise, with these two lines, you aren't you computing the MAP@k and also MAR@K?:
```

    print(sum(prec for prec in precisions.values()) / len(precisions))
    print(sum(rec for rec in recalls.values()) / len(recalls))
```

Thank you, Nic!

```
`from collections import defaultdict

from surprise import Dataset
from surprise import SVD
from surprise.model_selection import KFold


def precision_recall_at_k(predictions, k=10, threshold=3.5):
    '''Return precision and recall at k metrics for each user.'''

    # First map the predictions to each user.
    user_est_true = defaultdict(list)
    for uid, _, true_r, est, _ in predictions:
        user_est_true[uid].append((est, true_r))

    precisions = dict()
    recalls = dict()
    for uid, user_ratings in user_est_true.items():

        # Sort user ratings by estimated value
        user_ratings.sort(key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True)

        # Number of relevant items
        n_rel = sum((true_r >= threshold) for (_, true_r) in user_ratings)

        # Number of recommended items in top k
        n_rec_k = sum((est >= threshold) for (est, _) in user_ratings[:k])

        # Number of relevant and recommended items in top k
        n_rel_and_rec_k = sum(((true_r >= threshold) and (est >= threshold))
                              for (est, true_r) in user_ratings[:k])

        # Precision@K: Proportion of recommended items that are relevant
        precisions[uid] = n_rel_and_rec_k / n_rec_k if n_rec_k != 0 else 1

        # Recall@K: Proportion of relevant items that are recommended
        recalls[uid] = n_rel_and_rec_k / n_rel if n_rel != 0 else 1

    return precisions, recalls


data = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')
kf = KFold(n_splits=5)
algo = SVD()

for trainset, testset in kf.split(data):
    algo.fit(trainset)
    predictions = algo.test(testset)
    precisions, recalls = precision_recall_at_k(predictions, k=5, threshold=4)

    # Precision and recall can then be averaged over all users
    print(sum(prec for prec in precisions.values()) / len(precisions))
    print(sum(rec for rec in recalls.values()) / len(recalls))
`

items.title: Training specific users in the whole trainset for KNN based algorithms.
items.body:
--> Hey Nicolas, first I wanted to congratulate you, for the amazing job you have done with this library. Thank you for sharing your work with the community.

The situation is the following, I have two sources of data, one from Kaggle and one from my website. In order, to overcome the cold start problem, what I did is to merge both datasets so that I directly have a lot of ratings.

As far I understood, when we use the build_full_trainset() function for a KNN based algorithm, the algorithm basically calculates the similarity between all the users or between the items. Then this similarity is used to predict the ratings.

My questions: Is there a way to train only one user, i.e (in my understanding) calculate only the similarities between a user x and all the other users, without calculating all the remaining similarities. In other words, is there a way to calculate the similarity of a user from the dataset of my website with all the users from the kaggle dataset without calculating the similarity within the kaggle users.

I hope you will be able to give me a response.

Have a nice weekend.

Babas

items.title: Calculating est by dot product of latent matrices
items.body:
Hi Nicolas,
Greetings. So I am using SVDpp to predict the latent features for a given User/item combination. I am trying to manually calculate the est value by doing the dot product of values. 

I also referred to the already solved issue "https://github.com/NicolasHug/Surprise/issues/284". 

So this is how the code/formula looks like 
"algo = SVDpp()
trainset=fit_data.build_full_trainset()
algo.fit(trainset)

np.dot(algo.pu[trainset.to_inner_uid(u)], algo.qi[trainset.to_inner_iid(i)])+algo.trainset.global_mean+algo.bu[trainset.to_inner_uid(u)]+algo.bi[trainset.to_inner_iid(i)] 
"

However there is a deviation with the value calculated above and that of the predict method. I also considered the possibility of an offset but then the deviation was not constant.

Interesting point to note is that the same logic works when I use SVD instead of SVDpp. So I believe I am missing a couple of extra factors in the formula. It would be great if you can help me out here.

Please let me know should you need more information.

items.body:
I have a pandas dataframe containing 22,378 different users and ratings for 1,065 different items (games). After using SVDpp to train the model, I wanted to plot the items according to their qi value, to try to understand what each latent factor is representing. My problem is that the size of the latent factors, which I obtained through algo.qi, is smaller than the number of items. This means that I cannot map the qi values to the respective games. My code is as follows:

```
# Load data from pandas dataframe
reader = Reader(rating_scale=(1,5))
data = Dataset.load_from_df(cleaned_player_game[['username','gamename','star_rating']], reader)

# Train SVDpp with 5 latent factors using 3 fold cross validation
algo=SVDpp(n_factors=5)
cross_validate(algo, data, measures=['MAE'], cv=3, verbose=True)

# Iterate over trainset to get the ordered list of items according to their inner iid.
# This will then be used to match the qi values with the corresponding item
games = []
trainset = data.build_full_trainset()
for i in range(0,trainset.n_items):
    games.append(trainset.to_raw_iid(i))
```

The problem is that `algo.qi.shape` returns (1058,5) but `trainset.n_items` returns 1065. To my understanding and according to [issue 119](https://github.com/NicolasHug/Surprise/issues/119), algo.qi.shape should be an array of shape (n_items, n_factors). So in this case it should be (1065,5) and not (1058,5).

Why is qi missing 7 items?

EDIT:
After further investigation, it appears that the issue is related to the cross_validate method, because the shape of algo.qi changes according to the cv value. Smaller cv values result in a smaller algo.qi shape

Looking forward to your reply!

items.title: Not Really an Issue: Curiosity about not directly initializing pu and qi
items.body:
I am trying to build a recommender system with a dataset that will be growing over time. Normally I will get new users with new recommendations. Instead of running everything again, I thought that when using an algorithm like SVD or NMF it would be interesting to keep the movie coefficients qi. However, after a check in the source code, you only initialize those variables when the fit function is called. Is there a reason to do so and not initialize pu and qi when creating the algorithm? I tried to modify the source code and compile the package but I'm getting a lot of trouble with Cython. I also tried to clone the git repository and use python3 setup.py build but again I have problems with the .pyx files. I am not willing you to help me with those problems but rather I would like to know why pu and qi are not initialized when the algorithm is instantiated. 

Best.

Hi Nicolas, 

I am using svd to build a recommender. I was able to use the predict method to get estimated rating for user/item pair. I saw some weird results so I wanted to manually verify the ratings by calculating from dot product of the embedding vectors plus bias vectors. 

The number from predict method was quite different from my manually calculation. 

For example:

items.title: How to split my dataset into a train and test data but now, using cross_validate()
items.body:
#### Description


Hello, Nicolas!

Hope all is good! I am doing my master thesis and I am using your amazing Surprise package, which you made for the occasion (PhD thesis).

I wanted to ask you how can I use your cross_validate() class instead of GridSearch(SVD, param_grid, measures=['RMSE'], verbose=0).

I want to set cross_validate(whatever_algo,cv=10,n_jobs=-1). I have attached your original solution below. I added what I wanted (commented out, obviously)

Thank you very much in advance!

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
                            
                                                                           
```
from __future__ import (absolute_import, division, print_function,         
                        unicode_literals)      
import random                                                              
                                                                           
from surprise import SVD                                                   
from surprise import Dataset                                               
from surprise import accuracy                                              
from surprise import GridSearch                                            
                                                                           
                                                                           
# Load your full dataset.                                                  
data = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')                                     
raw_ratings = data.raw_ratings                                             
                                                                           
# shuffle ratings if you want                                              
random.shuffle(raw_ratings)                                                
                                                                           
# 90% trainset, 10% testset                                                
threshold = int(.9 * len(raw_ratings))                                     
trainset_raw_ratings = raw_ratings[:threshold]                             
test_raw_ratings = raw_ratings[threshold:]                                 
                                                                           
data.raw_ratings = trainset_raw_ratings  # data is now your trainset       
data.split(n_folds=3)                                                      
                                                                           
 
print('GRID SEARCH...')                                                    
param_grid = {'n_epochs': [5, 10], 'lr_all': [0.002, 0.005]}   

# Instead of GridSearch() use cross_validate()
# cross_validate =cross_validate(SVD(n_epochs = i,n_factors=10, biased=True), data_svd, measures=['rmse'], cv=10, verbose=True,n_jobs=-1)
            
grid_search = GridSearch(SVD, param_grid, measures=['RMSE'], verbose=0)    
grid_search.evaluate(data)                                                 
                                                                           
algo = grid_search.best_estimator['RMSE']                                  
                                                                           
# retrain on the whole train set                                           
trainset = data.build_full_trainset()                                      
algo.train(trainset)                                                       
                                                                           
# now test on the trainset                                                 
testset = data.construct_testset(trainset_raw_ratings)                     
predictions = algo.test(testset)                                           
print('Accuracy on the trainset:')                                         
accuracy.rmse(predictions)                 

```

items.title: Denominators in NMF are sometimes zero, causing NaNs in estimates. Use the solution from sklearn for this.
items.body:
https://github.com/NicolasHug/Surprise/blob/2efa8840ac2719050178d836c1d6904f9431f3c6/surprise/prediction_algorithms/matrix_factorization.pyx#L695

A simple fix is something like `user_denom[u, f] += max(qi[i, f] * est, EPSILON)`.

items.title: Is it the user rating error ?
items.body:
Load the local dataset of ml-100k as below

```
import pandas as pd
header = ['user_id','item_id','rating','timestamp']
src_data = pd.read_csv('ml-100k/u.data',sep = '\t',names = header)
src_data.head() 
```

And it display the data as below

```

user_id | item_id | rating | timestamp
-- | -- | -- | --
196 | 242 | 3 | 881250949
186 | 302 | 3 | 891717742
22 | 377 | 1 | 878887116
244 | 51 | 2 | 880606923
166 | 346 | 1 | 886397596
```

So, we got that user-196 gave item-242 rating 3.

Then, load the same data by surprise

```
import os
from surprise import Dataset, Reader
file_path = os.path.expanduser('ml-100k/u.data')
reader = Reader(line_format='user item rating timestamp', sep='\t')
data2 = Dataset.load_from_file(file_path, reader=reader)
```

and check the rating result of user-196 to item-242 as below

```
trainset2 = data2.build_full_trainset()
for (item, result) in trainset.ur[196]:
    if(item==242):
        print(result)
```

And got nothing, it seems there is no result for user-196 to item-242. But from first part of code block as above, we believe that user-196 gave item-242 rating 3 points.

Why we cannot get the rating information correctly by surprise ?

items.title: How to display the iterative process of ['RMSE']
items.body:
I want to draw an iterative graph of ['RMSE']. The x-axis is the number of iterations, but the reference example simply outputs the final value directly. Do you know how to display the iterative process of ['RMSE']?

We'll use the famous SVD algorithm.
algo = SVD()
algo = KNNBasic()
Run 5-fold cross-validation and print results
cross_validate(algo, data, measures=['RMSE', 'MAE'], cv=5, verbose=True)

items.title: Own dataset - RAM usage problem.
items.body:
Hello!
#### Description
I am implementing recommendation system for online shop. I am collecting items that user is watching, adding to cart and pays for. Currently I have 65k items "rated" by users. I have a problem with high RAM usage during computing similarity matrix. I tried using different similarity measures, but RAM usage is always high. Too high for my machine, therefore I get memory errors.

I tired chunking my input data:
```
tp = read_csv("all.csv", iterator=True, chunksize=1000)
df = concat(tp, ignore_index=True)
data = Dataset.load_from_df(df, reader=reader)
trainset = data.build_full_trainset()
sim_options = {'name': 'cosine', 'user_based': False}
global _, algo
start_time = time.time()
algo = KNNBaseline(sim_options=sim_options)
algo.fit(trainset)
```
but the problem is with `algo.fit(trainset)`.

Can it be optimised in any way? 

I saw an issue #208, where partial fitting is proposed, could this help in any way?

Or is there any way to make it work good on 4GB of RAM?

#### Versions
```
Windows-10-10.0.17763-SP0
Python 3.6.8 (tags/v3.6.8:3c6b436a57, Dec 24 2018, 00:16:47) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
surprise 1.0.6
```

items.title: Issue with the values of the ratings in test set
items.body:
Hi,

When running the example on Surprise's GitHub (and also working on my
own dataset), I noticed that, when building a test set, the ratings in
the test set all have the same value.

Here is some code to reproduce the issue:

from surprise import SVD
from surprise import Dataset
from surprise.model_selection import cross_validate

data = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')
trainset = data.build_full_trainset()
testset = trainset.build_anti_testset()

print(np.unique(np.array([r for _, _, r in testset()])))

Is there something I don't understand?

Thanks,

I am not sure if this is the right place to ask so apologies in advance if its not.

I am using the precision recall example from the FAQ  and I was wondering how to tune the threshold so that my results are meaningful. A the moment with a high threshold i get very high precision since there are no a lot of item with high rating. The data global mean is very skewed with a global mean of 1.5. Is there a guideline bast on the data set that could give me some insight?

thanks in advance!

items.title: GridSearch on pre-defined folds.
items.body:
Hi,

I want to tune hyperparamters by using your GridSearchCV function. The problem is that in my cross validation, i need to divide the folds first then apply some pre-processing procedures on training set before applying KNN or SVD.

Do you have any suggestion of how to use GridSearchCV for cases of pre-defined folds like me?

Thank you in advance.

Best,

Tam.

items.title: some problem in joblib
items.body:
#### Description
Hi,
I need your help. After I install surprise by 'conda install -c conda-forge scikit-surprise', anaconda reveal that surprise has already installed successfully. However, when I try to run the example code, I meet some problem. The error shows 'The 'joblib>=0.11' distribution was not found and is required by scikit-surprise' and I try to use 'pip install surprise', but it can't solve the problem. Anaconda shows the version of joblib is 0.12.5-py_0.
Thanks.


#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
**from surprise import SVD
from surprise import Dataset
from surprise import accuracy
from surprise.model_selection import train_test_split

data = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')

trainset, testset = train_test_split(data, test_size=.25)

algo = SVD()

algo.fit(trainset)
predictions = algo.test(testset)

accuracy.rmse(predictions)
```

```python

items.title: Mermory Error in Computing Similarities
items.body:
I am using the [Anime Dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/CooperUnion/anime-recommendations-database)
for creating my recommender system using KNNBasic Algorithm.It has about 7..6 million ratings.In the following line of code
`ratings = AnimeDataSet.load_ratings_dataset()
trainset = ratings.build_full_trainset()
alogorithm = KNNBasic(sim_options={
    'name': 'cosine',
    'user_based': True
})

alogorithm.fit(trainset)

similarities = alogorithm.compute_similarities()`


 I get the following error 



**Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "main.py", line 37, in <module>
    alogorithm.fit(trainset)
  File "E:\AI\RecSys\lib\site-packages\surprise\prediction_algorithms\knns.py", line 99, in fit
    self.sim = self.compute_similarities()
  File "E:\AI\RecSys\lib\site-packages\surprise\prediction_algorithms\algo_base.py", line 293, in compute_similarities
    sim = construction_func[name](*args)
  File "surprise/similarities.pyx", line 73, in surprise.similarities.cosine
    freq = np.zeros((n_x, n_x), np.int)
MemoryError**


I tried to reduce the size of the dataset file (which i should not.) and removed 7 million ratings from it
Even then I get the same error.
It even failed in google Collaboratory.
Thats too expensive of a memory work and I am clueless on how to escape it .
